Award.AwardTitle: A better understanding of recent changes of the CO2 system in the Western Arctic Ocean via field measurements from the summer 2014 CHINARE cruise
Award.AbstractNarration: This project would continue a successful collaboration between U.S. and Chinese scientists to study the exchange of carbon dioxide between the atmosphere and the surface waters of the Arctic Ocean. It involves the collection of high resolution underway pCO2 (partial pressure of carbon dioxide) data combined with discrete samples of water column pH, total dissolved inorganic carbon (DIC), alkalinity, calcium, nutrients, and oxygen during the Chinese Arctic Research Expedition (CHINARE) cruise in summer 2014. Together with historical data, the results will be used to constrain the variability of sea surface pCO2, air-to-sea CO2 flux, and their changes over time and to understand the underlying carbon cycling control mechanisms in the Western Arctic Ocean. The investigator hypothesizes that 1) sea surface pCO2 is highly variable in the Western Arctic Ocean and is controlled by multiple parameters that are climate-sensitive, and that current knowledge is insufficient to draw reliable conclusions regarding air-sea CO2 flux, controlling mechanisms and prediction of future changes, 2) high biological production (and CO2/DIC removal) areas have expanded from the southern areas in 1990s and early 2000s to the northern basins today along with the retreat of sea ice, and 3) riverine inorganic and organic carbon inputs have increased and they play an important role in controlling sea surface pCO2 and thus the net air-sea CO2 exchange flux in the western Arctic Ocean. This project would continue an active international collaboration and culture a Chinese Arctic carbon research team through fieldwork and data synthesis activities. The collaboration would incorporate these data into several U.S. and international databases. The project would also directly support a Ph.D. student.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Arctic Ocean and its surrounding lands have experienced physical and biological changes related to the global climate warming.  In the ocean, changes include atmospheric and ocean warming, sea-ice loss, increased freshwater accumulation, and high biological production in exposed surface waters and under thinner sea-ice. One particularly notable new normal since 2007 is the summer sea-ice retreat into the deep Arctic Ocean basins.  It has been predicted that the Arctic Ocean basins will be ice-free in summer within one to a few decades. An important question is what will the marine carbon dioxide (CO2) do in response to the warming and sea-ice retreat.

We have (1) collected high resolution underway pCO2 data and discrete sample-based water column pH, Dissolved Inorganic Carbon (DIC), and Total Alkalinity (TA) data during the Chinese National Arctic Research Expedition (CHINARE) cruises in summer 2014 and 2016 in the Western Arctic Ocean, (2) synthesized the new data with earlier data and understand the mechanisms controlling the recent changes in the CO2 system, and (3) improved international collaboration and bring CHINARE data to the international databases. Intellectual Merit: (1) We found the newly ice-free southern Canada Basin (~ 75ºN) had high pCO2 in summer 2014 and 2016 similar to the previous observation in 2008 and 2010, suggesting that this is a combined result of rapid CO2 uptake from the atmosphere into a highly stratified low salinity and low biological production surface water. However the high pCO2 area in 2014 was smaller than the previous years corresponding to a less severe sea-ice melt.  (2) We further confirmed our earlier speculation that a future ice-free Arctic Ocean may not be able to serve as a large CO2 sink for the atmosphere reported in a Science paper (Cai et al. 2010).  New data from summer 2010-2016, however, suggest that the high pCO2 region may have expanded to further north and has increased in value following the atmospheric pCO2 increase. (3) A synthesis of water column DIC and TA data from multiple trans-western Arctic Ocean cruises collected over nearly two decades (1994-2010) suggested a large expansion of acidifying seawater to both deeper depths and more northern latitudes. This work has resulted in a high impact paper in Nature Climate Change (Qi et al. 2017). These important results motivated us to propose here to continue to collect data to confirm our new findings and to understand the controlling mechanisms better. (Note a small budget was available near the end of this project and was used to support a graduate student to attend the 2016 cruise.). Broader Impacts: These findings, if confirmed by further observation, will have important implications for our prediction of both the future atmospheric CO2 uptake rate and rate of ocean acidification in the surface mixed layer.  One MS student (Andrew Collins) was supported (2013-2016) who attended the 2014 cruise and a Ph.D. student (Z. Ouyang, 2015-) has also been supported (who attended the 2016 cruise and will attend the 2018 cruise).  Cai also participated in workshops and international synthesis activities that promoted U.S. international collaboration with China and other countries in polar carbon cycle research.  Data Management products: Underway pCO2 data from 2008, 2010, 2012 and 2014 have been archived at various international databases. The 2016 data will be added to the databases soon. Total of four Publications including: Qi, D., Chen, L., Chen, B., Gao, Z., Zhong, W., Feely, R.A., Anderson, L.G., Sun, H., Chen, J., Chen, M., Zhan, L., Zhang, Y. and Cai, W.-J., 2017. Increase in acidifying water in the western Arctic Ocean. Nature Climate Change, 7(3): 195-199.
